sec.title: Annex 1: Determination of the UD friction parameters by experiment
Similarity between FMC formulations and Mohr–Coulomb formulations
sec.p: The linear Mohr-Coulomb (M-C) formulation for an UD lamina may be written as (A1)R¯τ=τn+μ·σnorτn=R¯τ-μ·σn. μ is an internal friction property of the UD material (usually termed friction coefficient) and R¯τ is the cohesion strength, corresponding to fracture plane resistance in Reference [28].
The nonlinear M-C formulations are given as: τnt 2=R¯τ parab·(R¯τ parab-μparab·σn).

sec.title: Relationship between the FMC friction parameters and Mohr–Coulomb
sec.p: *In-plane shear τn1(σn) IFF3. For jn-plane (2D) stresses, equation (14e) gives a nonlinear M-C relationship between the direct stress σn and the shear stress τn1 as the following equation: (τn1,σn)≡(τ21,σ2) is valid. To avoid the complexity of solving that relationship, a simple equation was reported in Reference [6] (A2)|τ21|=R¯⊥||-μ⊥||·σ2.

Due to σn=σ2, the fracture angle is Θfp ∘=0, it can be concluded from Figure A1 that the cohesion strength equates the shear strength, R¯τ ⊥||=R¯⊥||. The property μ⊥|| is determined like b⊥|| from a curve fit of the IFF3 test data. Figure A1.
Stresses at shear failure IFF3.

*Transverse shear τnt(σn) IFF2. Here, the unknown angle is Θfp c>45∘. Following Figure A2, Mohr-Coulomb formulation may be written as: (A3)τnt=R¯τ ⊥⊥-μ⊥⊥·σn. Figure A2.
Lamina stresses and Mohr stresses at shear failure IFF2 (wedge failure).

Transferring the FMC formulation, equation (A3), into a Mohr-Coulomb formulation, is to express the invariants not any more in lamina stresses but in corresponding Mohr stresses, equations (14d) and (6d), (A4)b⊥ τ·(σn-σt)2+4τnt 2+(b⊥ τ-1)·(σn+σt)=R¯⊥ c.

Above formulation involves the still mentioned stress σt which cannot be representative for a Mohr envelope curve. However, despite taking this as a presumption, one has nevertheless to prove that σt comes out of the equation when inserting apparent stress boundary conditions into the former equation. These conditions are the strength points. A further necessary condition when transferring the FMC formulation into a Mohr one is that the slope of Mohr’s circle must be equal to the slope of Mohr’s envelope curve in the common touching point. Θfp=Θfp ∘·π/180∘c=cos(Θfp),s=sin(Θfp),C=cos(2Θfp)=c2-s2S=sin(2Θfp)=2·s·c.C2+S2=1

The transformation of the lamina stresses into Mohr stresses is depicted in Figure A2. Assuming τ23 = 0, which does not confine the generality because otherwise the principal stresses σi pr can be taken, the transformation,28 (A5)[σ1σnσtτntτtlτnl]=[1000000c2s22sc000s2c2-2sc000-scsc(c2-s2)000000c-s0000sc][σ1σ2σ3τ23τ31τ21] will lead to the relationships (A6a and b)σn=c2σ2+s2σ3,σt=s2σ2+c2σ3, (A6a> >and> >b) (A6c)τnt=s·c·(-σ2+σ3)=s·c·(-σ)=-0.5·S·σ, when applying the advantageous additional theorems with Mohr stresses and when using the abbreviation (σ2-σ3)=σ. Mind: Mohr combines τn=τnt2+τn12. Further holds (A7a)I23-5=2σ2·τ21 2+2σ3·τ31 2+4τ23τ31τ21. (15) which is to be resolved for σt yielding (A7b)σt=σn-C·σ.

Then, the slope in the touching point is to be determined via the derivatives (A8a)dσn/dΘfp=-2·s·c·σ=-σ·S=-σ·sin(2Θfp), (A8b)dτnt/dΘfp=-0.5·2·C=-σ·cos(2Θfp). They deliver one common equation for the slope of the envelope curve (A9)dτnt/dσn=cotan(2Θfp)=C/S.

An implicit differentiation of the failure function F⊥ τ (A10a and b)I23-5=2σ2·τ21 2+2σ3·τ31 2+4τ23τ31τ21. (15) gives the necessary analogous second equation. Dividing equation (A10b) by equation (A10a) one obtains (A11)dτntdσn=-b⊥ τ-1R¯⊥ c+b⊥ τ·(σn-σt)(σn-σt)2+4τnt 2·R¯⊥ c4b⊥ τ·τnt(σn-σt)2+4τnt 2·R¯⊥ c.
The minus sign is due to inverse differentiation. Equating the slope equations (A9) and (A11) yields after reformulation CS=(b⊥ τ-1)·(σn-σt)2+4τnt 2+b⊥ τ·(σn-σt)-4b⊥ τ·τnt.

Into this combined equation, as the already mentioned stress boundary condition, the given fracture strength point σ2=-R¯⊥ c=σ together with the fracture angle Θfp⇒Θfp c has to be inserted. This leads via the equations (A6) and (A7) to σn-σt=Cfp c·σandτnt=-0.5·Sfp c·σ.
Finally, when taking the negative root, one obtains the following (A12)I23-5=2σ2·τ21 2+2σ3·τ31 2+4τ23τ31τ21. (15)
As can be seen in the equation above: The stress σt has no influence.
The final step is resolving equation (A12) for b⊥ c, which results in the following relation (A13)b⊥ τ=1/(1+Cfp c)withCfp c=cos(2·Θfp c∘180∘·π).

sec.title: Relationship between friction parameter b⊥ τ and ‘linear’ Mohr–Coulomb parameters
sec.p: Searching for a direct relationship between the FMC and the Mohr-Coulomb parameters requires a comparison of coefficients (in the strength point R¯⊥ c). At first equation (A1) is employed to follow the trend in equation (A3) (A14a)τnt=R¯τ ⊥⊥-μ⊥⊥·σn with R¯τ ⊥⊥ denoting the transverse cohesive strength. Then the IFF2 failure condition equation (A4) is applied leading to the equation (A14b)I23-5=2σ2·τ21 2+2σ3·τ31 2+4τ23τ31τ21. (15)

In order to compare equation (14a) with equation (14b), both have to be firstly squared and secondly compared with respect to the coefficients. This delivers (A15a)I23-5=2σ2·τ21 2+2σ3·τ31 2+4τ23τ31τ21. (15)
The comparison requires the fulfilment of two conditions for the friction coefficients I23-5=2σ2·τ21 2+2σ3·τ31 2+4τ23τ31τ21. (15) and (A15b)μ⊥⊥,2=(b⊥ τ-1)/b⊥ τ=-Cfp c.
This means ‘over determined’. The latter and simpler equation μ⊥⊥,2 represents a slightly smaller value and will be applied as μ⊥⊥.

sec.title: Experimental determination of a value for the friction coefficient μ⊥⊥
sec.p:
The determination of the friction coefficient μ⊥⊥ is performed for the linear approach, only. From the evaluation of the test data in Reference [29], see also Figure A3 and equation (A13), the measured values θfp c∘=55∘ (Cfp c=-0.342), R¯⊥ c=104MPa were computed. Hence, when applying equation (A13), it is obtained:
FMC approach:
b⊥ τ·I4=R¯⊥ c-(b⊥ τ-1)·I2,⇒b⊥ τ=11+Cfp c)=1.52, andbfriction=b⊥ τ-1=0.52;
Mohr-Coulomb approach:
τn=R¯τ ⊥⊥-μ⊥⊥·σn,⇒μ⊥⊥=-Cfp c=0.342,R¯τ ⊥⊥=0.5·R⊥ c·Cfp c+1=36.1MPa. Figure A3.
Linear IFF2 approach and validation by test data. Glass/epoxy, Reference [29]. Friction angle: tanρ=-μ⊥⊥.
Note: Assuming τ23=0 is accurate for the test specimen. The determination of the material friction parameter b⊥ τ from test generates a generally valid value.

sec.title: Conclusions

list-item.p: As the matrices of the TCs seem to be semi-brittle as data set is proposed for the UD analyses: θfp c∘=50∘, b⊥ τ=1.21 or μ⊥⊥=0.17, R¯τ ⊥⊥=43.6MPa,
All parameter values depend on the chosen Mohr-Coulomb model (linear or parabolic or…).

sec.p:
Figure A4 eventually visualizes the received Mohr envelope curves for the in-plane and out-of-plane situation in case of the chosen linear model. Figure A4.
Mohr–Coulomb failure envelopes τn1(σn), τnt(σn).

sec.title: Annex 2: calculation procedure
sec.p:
Figure A5 presents a flow chart of the nonlinear calculation procedure. The solution procedure of the nonlinear analysis aims to establish static equilibrium at each load step after material properties have been changed. When Eff=1 has been reached, this total combined stress effort value is kept constant throughout the degradation procedure till the fibres take over above additional load. After the first IFF and after reaching Eff=1, the associated mode stress effort Effcrit mode=σeq mode/R mode is left as a decaying fracture energy portion (numerical damping) in the interaction equation. Note that σeq mode decreases in the softening domain and R mode is kept constant. Figure A5.
Nonlinear calculation scheme of the self-correcting secant modulus method. Matrix weakening is considered in the degradation box.

In areas where failure modes do interact, it is a good practice to consider the interaction between the modes in the following manner: The secant moduli E2sec and G21sec are taken from the σ2(ε2)-curves or the τ21(γ21)-curve not just at the stresses σeq ⊥τ, σeq ⊥σ, or σeq ⊥|| resulting from the stress and strain analysis. Their values are taken in the 'hardening branch' at a slightly higher stress as follows (25a)σeq,corr mode=σeq mode·ftrf with the trigger factor for hardening (25b)I23-5=2σ2·τ21 2+2σ3·τ31 2+4τ23τ31τ21. (15) to consider a mode-combined degradation effort. By this approach, slightly lower secant moduli are provided for the next calculation loop; lower than those that would result without the correction by the triggering approach. The controlling parameter is the ratio of ‘total stress effort’ Eff to ‘critical mode stress effort’. Naturally, this triggering approach is already active before the onset of a distinct IFF.
Once IFF has been reached, the secant modulus Esec(σeq mode) can be determined by applying equation (33).

def.p: UD material’s internal “friction parameters” of the FMC-based model
Elastic moduli of a UD lamina in the directions x1≡1=||, x2≡⊥, x3≡⊥
Resultant (global) stress effort of all interacting failure modes
Stress effort of a UD-lamina in a distinct failure mode
Elastic filament (fibre) modulus in fibre (x1) direction
Elastic filament (fibre) modulus transversal to fibre direction
Tensile and compressive failure strain of a UD-lamina in x1 direction
Failure functions for FF and IFF modes
Reduction factor or function to consider the 2ndTg effect
Shear modulus of a UD lamina in the x1 – x2 plane (≡G||⊥); in the x3 – x2 plane (≡G⊥⊥)
Secant shear modulus in the x1 – x2 plane
Invariants of the isotropic matrix material
Pressure on the faces of the specimen (absolute value)
Average measured strength, strength design allowable for design verification (an A- or a B-value)
Tensile, compressive stress values at 0.2% plastic strain ≡ yield strength (R0.2 denotes both properties)
Cohesive strength of a ductile behaving material
UD tensile and compressive strength parallel to the fibre direction
UD tensile and compressive strength transverse to the fibre direction
UD in-plane shear strength, transverse/parallel to the fibre direction
Definition for the triaxiality value Tr=(I1/3)/3J2=σm/σeq Mises, σeq Mises=3J2 or in Lode coordinates Tr=[2/3]·(I1/3)/2J2 uniaxial: Tr = 1/3
Coordinates of the UD lamina (x1 = fibre direction ||, x2 = direction transverse to the fibre ⊥, x3 = thickness direction)
Normal strains of a UD lamina
Shear strains of a UD lamina
Major Poisson’s ratio in the WWFE-II (≡ν⊥|| in VDI 2014)
Poisson’s ratio in the transversal plane (≡ν23)
Parameter which represents the 120°-symmetry of brittle isotropic materials
Designation of the fracture plane angle
Internal friction coefficient of the isotropic material
Internal friction coefficients of the transversely-isotropic material model
Effective hydrostatic stress in the constrained matrix material (absolute value)
Normal stresses in a UD lamina
Principal stresses in an isotropic material
Compressive stress across and tensile stress along the fibre direction
Stresses parallel and transverse to the fibre direction (symbolic denotation)
Average in-plane stresses of the laminate
Equivalent stresses of a mode (σeq ||σ,σeq ||τ,σeq ⊥σ,σeq ⊥τ,σeq ⊥||) which include load-induced mechanical stresses and residual stresses
Filament stress in x1 direction; in x2 direction
Average stress loading a laminate’s face or cross section
Associated shear stresses of a UD lamina
Shear stresses transverse/parallel and transverse/transverse to the fibre direction
Mixed Failure Domain (interaction of several failure modes)
Effective hydrostatic stress and effective temperature difference at curing (stress free temperature – room temperature)
Denotes stress from external applied load, residual stress
Normal, tangential to the fibre plane of the UD lamina
Failure either induced by Mohr’s shear or by Mohr’s normal stress acting at the physical fracture plane
Transverse, parallel to fibre direction of a UD lamina
0.2 remaining plastic strain (technical onset of yielding)
Principal stresses in an isotropic material
Typical or average (sometimes the statistical mean) needed when modelling
Designation of transverse plane (as subscript and superscript)
